name: Morog Polao
instructions: Wash the rice and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
Heat the ghee in a large pot. Add the cinnamon stick, cardamom pods, cloves, and bay leaf, and fry for a few seconds.
Add the sliced onions and fry until they turn golden brown.
Add the ginger and garlic paste, and fry for another minute.
Add the chicken pieces and fry until they are golden brown.
Add the plain yogurt, green chili, and salt. Stir well.
Add the soaked rice and fry for a few minutes until the rice is coated with the spices.
Add the water and saffron soaked in warm milk. Stir well.
Bring the mixture to a boil. Then, reduce the heat to low and cover the pot with a lid.
Cook for 20-25 minutes or until the rice is fully cooked and the water has evaporated.
Remove from heat and let it rest for 10 minutes.
Fluff the rice with a fork and serve hot with raita or salad.

name: Kacchi Biriyani

ingredients.name: Saffron
ingredients.quantity: 1/4 tsp, dissolved in 1/4 cup of warm milk

instructions: Wash the basmati rice and soak it in water for 30 minutes.
In a mixing bowl, marinate the mutton pieces with yogurt, garlic paste, ginger paste, lemon juice, green chili, and salt. Keep aside for 2 hours.
In a large pot, boil water with whole spices and salt. Add the soaked rice and cook for 7-8 minutes. Drain the water and keep the rice aside.
In a deep-bottomed pan, heat ghee over medium heat. Add sliced onions and fry until they turn golden brown.
Add the marinated mutton pieces and cook until the meat is tender and the gravy is thick.
Preheat the oven to 180Â°C. In a large baking dish, spread a layer of cooked rice at the bottom.
Add the mutton gravy on top of the rice layer, spreading it evenly.
Add another layer of rice on top of the mutton gravy. Repeat the process until all the rice and mutton are used up.
Pour the saffron milk over the rice and cover the baking dish with foil.
Bake in the preheated oven for 30-35 minutes.
Remove the foil and bake for an additional 5-10 minutes to allow the top layer of rice to crisp up.
Garnish with fried onions and serve hot with raita and salad.

name: Panta Ilish
instructions: Clean and wash the hilsa fish thoroughly. Cut it into pieces and keep aside.
Boil 6 cups of water in a large pot. Add the hilsa fish pieces and 1 tsp of salt to the pot.
Cook the fish over medium heat for about 15-20 minutes, until it is fully cooked.
Remove the fish pieces from the pot and allow them to cool down.
In a separate pot, mix the cooked rice with 2 cups of water and 1 tsp of salt. Leave it overnight to ferment.
In the morning, mix the fermented rice with the remaining 2 cups of water to make a watery consistency.
Add the cooked fish pieces to the rice mixture and mix well.
Heat the mustard oil in a pan. Add the chopped onion and green chili, and fry until the onion turns golden brown.
Pour the fried onion and green chili mixture over the rice and fish mixture.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve chilled.

name: Bhuna Khichuri
instructions: Wash the rice and dal together and soak in water for at least 30 minutes. Drain and keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan and add the cubed potatoes, carrots, cauliflower, and green peas. Fry for 2-3 minutes and keep aside.
In the same pan, add the chopped onion and fry until golden brown.
Add the ginger and garlic paste to the pan and fry for a minute.
Add the chopped tomato and fry until it turns mushy.
Add turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt to the pan. Fry for 1-2 minutes.
Add the rice and dal mixture to the pan and fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add the fried vegetables to the pan and mix well.
Add 3 cups of water to the pan and mix well. Cover the pan with a lid and let it cook for 20-25 minutes on low flame.
Once the khichuri is cooked, add ghee and mix well.
Serve hot with papad and your favorite pickle.

name: Chingri Malai Curry
instructions: Heat oil in a pan and add the bay leaf, cinnamon stick, and cardamom pods. Fry for a few seconds until fragrant.
Add the chopped onion and fry until golden brown.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger, and fry for another minute.
Add the turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, and salt. Fry for a minute or two, until the spices are fragrant.
Add the coconut milk and green chilies. Bring to a boil and let simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the prawns and cook for another 5 minutes, until they are pink and cooked through.
Add the ghee and give everything a stir.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Sorshe Ilish
instructions: Take 2 tbsp of mustard seeds, turmeric powder, and salt in a grinder. Add a little water and grind into a smooth paste.
Marinate the hilsa fish pieces with the mustard paste and green chilies. Keep aside for 10-15 minutes.
Heat mustard oil in a pan and fry the fish pieces until golden brown. Keep aside.
In the same pan, add the remaining mustard seeds and fry until they start to pop.
Add the chopped onion and fry until golden brown.
Add the minced garlic and fry for another minute.
Add the cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, sugar, and salt. Fry for a minute or two, until the spices are fragrant.
Add water and bring to a boil. Let simmer for 2-3 minutes.
Add the fried fish pieces and green chilies. Cover and simmer for another 5-7 minutes, until the fish is cooked through and the gravy has thickened.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Shutki Bhuna
instructions: Soak the dried fish in water for at least 30 minutes to soften it. Drain the water and rinse the fish with fresh water.
Heat oil in a pan and fry the fish until golden brown. Remove from the pan and set aside.
In the same pan, add more oil if necessary and fry the sliced onions until golden brown.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger, and fry for another minute.

Add the chopped tomato, green chilies, and all the spices (turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt). Fry for a few minutes until the tomato is soft and everything is fragrant.
Add the fried fish back to the pan and stir to combine with the masala. Add 1/2 cup of water and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and let simmer for 10-15 minutes, until the fish is cooked through and the sauce has thickened.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Ilish Bhaja
instructions: Rub the fish pieces with turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Heat the mustard oil in a frying pan over medium-high heat.
When the oil is hot, carefully place the fish pieces in the pan. Fry them for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fish from the pan and place them on a paper towel to drain excess oil.
Serve hot with steamed rice and lemon wedges.

name: Beef Curry
instructions: Heat oil in a pan and add the chopped onions. Fry until golden brown.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger, and fry for another minute.
Add the turmeric powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, red chili powder, and salt. Fry for a minute or two, until the spices are fragrant.
Add the chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Fry for a few minutes, until the tomatoes have broken down and become saucy.
Add the beef and fry for a few minutes, until the meat is browned on all sides.
Add water and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and let simmer for 30-40 minutes, until the beef is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or bread.

name: Chicken Roast
instructions: Preheat the oven to 375Â°F (190Â°C).
In a small bowl, mix together the garlic, ginger, lemon juice, salt, black pepper, paprika, and rosemary.
Rub the spice mixture all over the chicken, including under the skin.
Place the chicken in a roasting pan and drizzle with olive oil.
Roast the chicken in the preheated oven for 1 hour and 30 minutes, or until the internal temperature of the thickest part of the chicken reaches 165Â°F (74Â°C).
Remove the chicken from the oven and let it rest for 10 minutes.
Melt the butter in a small saucepan over low heat.
Carve the chicken and drizzle the melted butter over the top before serving.

name: Kala Bhuna
instructions: Heat the oil in a pan and fry the onions until golden brown.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger, and fry for another minute.
Add the beef and fry on high heat for 5-6 minutes until browned.
Add the turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Fry for a few minutes until the spices are fragrant.
Add the chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Fry until the tomatoes have softened and the oil has separated from the masala.
Add a cup of water, cover the pan, and simmer for 30-40 minutes until the beef is cooked through and the gravy has thickened.
Serve hot with rice or naan bread.

name: Mutton Curry
instructions: In a pressure cooker, heat the oil and fry the onions until golden brown.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger and fry for another minute.
Add the mutton pieces and fry on high heat until browned.
Add the turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Fry for a few minutes until the spices are fragrant.
Add the chopped tomatoes and fry until the oil has separated from the masala.
Add the yogurt and continue to cook for a few minutes, stirring constantly.
Add 2 cups of water, cover the pressure cooker, and cook until the mutton is tender (usually about 25 minutes).
Sprinkle garam masala on top and serve hot with rice or naan bread.

name: Bhapa Pitha
instructions: In a mixing bowl, add rice flour, grated coconut, grated jaggery, cardamom powder, and salt. Mix well.
Gradually add water to the mixture while stirring constantly to make a smooth batter. Make sure there are no lumps.
Grease a baking dish or thali with oil. Pour the batter into the dish and level it with a spoon.
Cover the dish with a lid or foil. Heat a pot of water on the stove and bring it to a boil.
Place the baking dish into the pot, cover it and steam for 30-35 minutes or until the pitha is cooked through.
Remove from the heat and let it cool for a few minutes before cutting into pieces.
Serve hot and enjoy your delicious Bhapa Pitha!

name: Nakshi Pitha
instructions: In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour and salt. Gradually add water and milk to form a smooth batter. The batter should be thin enough to spread but not too thin.
In a separate pan, heat jaggery on low heat until it melts. Add grated coconut and crushed cardamom pods. Mix well and remove from heat.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat. Grease the pan with oil.
Pour a small amount of batter onto the pan and spread it out in a circular motion to form a thin crepe.
Add a spoonful of the jaggery-coconut mixture onto the center of the crepe. Fold the crepe over the mixture to form a half-moon shape.
Use a toothpick or the tip of a sharp knife to make decorative patterns on the top of the pitha.
Cook the pitha on both sides until golden brown.
Repeat the process until all the batter and filling is used up.
Serve hot or at room temperature as a dessert or snack.

name: Chomchom

ingredients.name: Saffron
ingredients.notes: soaked in 2 tbsp of warm milk

instructions: In a large pot, bring the milk to a boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally.
Add the diluted lemon juice to the boiling milk and stir until the milk solids separate from the whey. Turn off the heat.
Pour the milk through a muslin cloth and wash the milk solids under running water to remove the lemon flavor.
Squeeze out any excess water from the milk solids and knead for 5 minutes to form a smooth dough.
Shape the dough into small oblongs or balls and set aside.
In another pot, combine the sugar, water, and cardamom powder and bring to a boil over medium heat. Stir until the sugar has dissolved.
Add the shaped dough pieces to the sugar syrup and cook for 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the chomchoms have doubled in size and are cooked through.
Turn off the heat and add the soaked saffron and chopped pistachios to the pot.
Allow the chomchoms to cool in the syrup before transferring to a serving dish.
Garnish with silver leaf and serve chilled.

name: Falooda

ingredients.name: Falooda sev
ingredients.notes: vermicelli noodles made from corn starch

ingredients.name: Chopped mixed nuts
ingredients.notes: such as almonds, cashews, and pistachios

instructions: Soak the basil seeds in 1/2 cup of water for 30 minutes.
Cook the falooda sev in boiling water for 8-10 minutes or until soft. Drain and rinse with cold water to prevent sticking.
In a glass, add 1 tbsp of rose syrup and a few basil seeds.
Add a layer of the cooked falooda sev.
Add a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
Repeat the layers until the glass is almost full.
Pour the milk over the layers, leaving some space on top for the chopped nuts.
Add a few chopped nuts on top and garnish with a cherry or strawberry.
Serve chilled.

name: Jilapi

ingredients.name: Saffron
ingredients.notes: dissolved in 1 tbsp of warm water

instructions: In a mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, corn flour, baking powder, and turmeric powder. Mix well.
Add the sour yogurt and water. Mix well to form a smooth batter. The consistency should be similar to a pancake batter.
Cover the bowl with a lid or plastic wrap and let the batter ferment for 6-8 hours, or overnight at room temperature.
After the batter has fermented, heat the sugar and water in a saucepan on medium heat. Stir until the sugar dissolves.
Add the crushed cardamom and saffron. Let the mixture come to a boil and then simmer on low heat for 10-15 minutes until it thickens into a syrup.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan or wok over medium heat.
Pour the batter into a piping bag or squeeze bottle. Pipe the batter into the hot oil in a circular motion to form spiral shapes. Fry until golden brown on both sides.
Remove the fried jilapi with a slotted spoon and immediately dip them into the warm syrup. Let them soak for a few minutes before serving.

name: Payesh
instructions: In a heavy-bottomed pot, bring the milk to a boil over medium-high heat.
Add the rinsed and drained rice, bay leaf, and crushed cardamom to the pot.
Stir the mixture frequently to prevent the rice from sticking to the bottom of the pot.
Lower the heat to medium-low and let the rice cook for about 1 hour or until the milk has thickened and the rice is cooked through.
Stir in the sugar, raisins, sliced almonds, and pistachios, and let the mixture simmer for another 10 minutes until the sugar has dissolved and the nuts have softened.
Remove the bay leaf from the pot and discard.
Serve the payesh warm or chilled, garnished with additional sliced nuts, if desired.

name: Borhani
instructions: In a blender, mix the yogurt, water, mint leaves, coriander leaves, green chili, grated ginger, cumin powder, salt, sugar, and lemon juice until smooth.
Taste and adjust the seasoning, adding more salt or sugar as needed.
Chill the borhani in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes.
Serve the borhani in glasses, garnished with a sprig of mint leaves or a slice of lemon.

name: Lassi
instructions: In a blender, combine the yogurt, water, sugar, and cardamom powder. Blend until smooth.
Add a few ice cubes and blend again until smooth.
Pour the lassi into glasses and garnish with mint leaves.
Serve chilled and enjoy!
